item.title: üåü Fedora ‚Äî My Experience
item.description:
Why I Chose Fedora

As a computer vision developer, the following are especially important to me:

  • Stability for long-running computations
  • Up-to-date versions of Python and scientific libraries
  • GPU support for working with neural networks

What I Like

  1. DNF package manager ‚Äì fast and convenient
  2. Automatic updates without user intervention
  3. Integration with Podman for project containerization
  4. Wayland support ‚Äì I really noticed smoother animations

Setup Specifics

I had to tinker a bit with:

  • NVIDIA drivers (solved it in 2 hours)
  • Setting up the Python environment for TensorFlow
  • Optimizing power consumption on a laptop

Tips for Beginners

  1. Start with Fedora Workstation ‚Äì the most stable version
  2. Install rpmfusion for full codec support
  3. Try Toolbox for isolated development environments
  4. Don‚Äôt be afraid of the command line ‚Äì it‚Äôs especially friendly in Fedora

Conclusion

After six months of use, this is my primary OS for work and research. I recommend it to fellow developers! üöÄ

item.title: üåü The fifth week is the final breakthrough
item.description:
Main achievements

  1. I have almost completed my project on the analysis of medical images - it remains to complete the documentation
  2. I have mastered the new features of PyCharm for code profiling
  3. Improved the project interface, making it more user-friendly
  4. Conducted the first successful tests on real data

Technical Details

  • Implemented multithreaded image processing
  • Wrote automated tests for 85% of the codebase
  • Optimized memory usage, reducing consumption by 20%.%

Impressions

I suddenly discovered that:

  • Documenting the code turned out to be more exciting than I thought.
  • Profiling is like a detective investigation
  • Colleagues at the university started asking for advice on Python

Plans

  1. Prepare the final presentation
  2. Write an article about your decision for the university blog
  3. Start exploring the possibilities of publishing the project as open source

item.title: üöÄ The fourth week is a breakthrough in the project
item.description:
Key achievements of the week

  1. Completed the main functionality of her individual computer vision project
  2. I have mastered PyCharm Professional for working with Python projects
  3. Improved model accuracy by 12% after algorithm optimization
  4. Received the first positive feedback from the supervisor

Workflow

Switching to a professional IDE turned out to be a real game-changer:

  • Auto-completion of the code saves a lot of time
  • Built-in debugging tools help you find errors faster
  • Jupyter Notebook support is convenient for experimentation

Plans for next week

  1. Write tests for the main modules
  2. Prepare a presentation of interim results
  3. Start working on the web interface for the project
  4. Explore the possibilities of integration with cloud services

Despite the busy schedule, I feel inspired by the visible progress!

item.title: üå± Git in Modern Development
item.description:
Why Git Changed Development

As a computer vision developer, I deal daily with the need to:

  • Experiment with different approaches without the fear of “breaking” working code
  • Collaborate on algorithms with colleagues
  • Track changes in complex mathematical models

Git handles these tasks better than any of its predecessors.

Evolution of VCS: From RCS to Git

Local Systems (RCS)

  • ‚úîÔ∏è Simplicity
  • ‚úñÔ∏è No team collaboration
  • ‚úñÔ∏è Risk of history loss

Centralized Systems (SVN)

  • ‚úîÔ∏è Shared codebase
  • ‚úñÔ∏è Single point of failure
  • ‚úñÔ∏è Internet dependency

Distributed Systems (Git)

  • ‚úîÔ∏è Full history on every developer’s machine
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Work offline
  • ‚úîÔ∏è Flexible workflows (GitHub Flow, Git Flow)

Practical Aspects of Git

What I Like:

  1. Branching ‚Äì I create feature branches for each experiment
  2. Staging area ‚Äì precise control over commits
  3. .gitignore ‚Äì keeps temporary model files out of version control
